This is only possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

title: Steam Controller D-Pad for Analog Stick

description.text:
[IN BETA]

I created a reddit thread over on reddit starting with Version #1, this is currently Version #2. I encourage you to make Version #3 as Version #2 is all I need for now.
Reddit thread now archived @ https://www.reddit.com/r/SteamControllerMods/comments/45b1it/joystick_to_dpad_mod_3d_printed/

[Description]

An alternate joystick for the analog stick to be able to use the joystick more effectively as a D-Pad, whilst still being able to use it as a joystick when required. Designed for use with the Steam controller. Designed in two parts so that one is beneath the plastic shell and the d pad above.

[Current Version Status]

I have updated the model on Shapeways and ordered it in Black Acrylic, the model is in Beta on Shapeways, however bear in mind that I won't be recieving it until March (what with being in the UK), so it may have unforseen problems. When I have finished modifying the design I will take it out of Beta. The clips from Version #1 (which have been replaced in favour of the screw design) have all broken, so there could well be issues with this design that I have not thought of, especially seeing as how the dome was too thick last time round. (This should have been corrected now, however I will have to wait and see.)

I have modified the design to mitigate the cons of Version #1, so hopefully Version #2 will need no further modification (at least in the short run, and until I get more ideas should there be a better way to make a D-Pad-like Joystick).

description.text:
This is a multi part accessory holder for the most common Aeropress accessories.
It's designed to hold the paper filter holder, stirrer and scoop that come with the coffee maker, as well as one of the Able Fine Disk metal filters if you attach three copies of the finger STLs.
The wooden post holding the tool holder + finger attachment is common 3/8" diameter dowel, and was cut to 5" lengths. All parts were glued together using epoxy.

NOTE If you downloaded the original STLs without the _mm suffix, those files are in inch format and need to be scaled in your slicer. The new _mm files are in millimeter format so no scaling should be required.

description.text:
This is my redesigned fan mount for both the hotend heatsink fan and the nozzle fan. It combines both fans into a single mount. Note that this fan shroud uses 50mm x 50mm. The stock fans are 40mm x 40mm.

You will also need 2x M3x8 and 2x M3x16 or 20.

It uses the pre-existing holes in the x-axis carriage to mount. I have noticed vastly improved cooling performance especially with ABS. The old hotend heatsink fan used to blow lots of cold air onto the print bed. This design eradicates that issue while better directing the nozzle fan air to the print itself.

03-16-17 UPDATE: I've added a new version with a larger opening on the part cooling fan. The opening is also semi-surrounding the nozzle on this version. Also, it sits slightly higher from the bed than my original design. Both work great, take your pick! It is in ready to print orientation.

I can now confirm that printing this in PETG works just as well as ABS.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2 mm

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

I would not recommend printing this in PLA as it is very near the hotend. I used ABS and it works great. Supports are required for the lip that the nozzle fan rests on and nowhere else. I have included two supports in my stl. Ensure that the bottom of these supports are aligned with your print bed in your slicer.
Remove all supports. You may have to sort of slide the fans in as it is a tight fit.

comments.text: I like the two piece design. I have tried other options on the site, and they have one major flaw. The nozzle. When printing with ABS I don't want any part cooling. The other designs have blocking dampers that can be installed. The eventual problem is local heat from the heater block eventually warps, then melts the nozzle. Being able to remove the nozzle for ABS and attach it for PLA or PET seems like a great design.

I was making spinners for my boys and ran out of bearings to use as weights. We have a lot of marbles around so modified a couple spinners to use 15.5mm marbles instead of steel weights or bearings.

(Standard Marble size is about 15.5 - 15.7mm)

They are made where the marbles can be changed out if they want to mix or have different colors.

On the curved Spinner I mad a cut so marble can be inserted easily and it is secure.
You can use razor blade of small saw to make the cut.

Just as FYI on my printer I had to print PLA @104% and ABS @ 105% to make bearing go in easier

Enjoy

description.text: This is a model of the composite link 2_21#_5_2_1. There are actually two versions of this composite link, depending on which component of the link 5_2_1 the Hopf link 2_2_1 is attached to. Both are given here. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. title: Up! Mini Fan Mod for PLA

description.text:
UP! Mini Fan Mod for PLA

I had some difficulties printing PLA with my Up! Mini.

I've already printed some other fan mods I've found on thingiverse but I wasn't satisfied with them. So I designed my own fan holder.

The fan holder fits the original "Extruder Cable Box V12.UP3".

As you can see in the pictures, the fan is located off-center so it blows some air directly to the bearing as well as on the 35x35x10mm heatsink.
After the air passed the heatsink it gets directed to the back of the stepper motor. You can put some heatsinks on the back of the motor as well for additional cooling.

Parts I've used:

  • Fan holder
  • 40x40x10mm 12V 3-pin fan
  • 2x M3x16 screw
  • 2x M3 nut
  • 35x35x10mm heatsink

description.text: This is customizable channel based on the FTC part. There is a .txt file that you can download(copy-past is funky in Thingiverse). All you need to do is change the two values in the parenthesis in "channel1(5,2):". The first value dictates how meany holes the channel should have. The second value controls how much distance there is between the top of the circle to the edge of the channel. Also if you want to have a version that does not have the alternating hole design then instead of "channel1" do "channel". I am open to suggestions.

title: No Soliciting Girl Scout Cookies Sign

description.text:
It's Girl Scout cookie time. There's only one kind of visitor that we don't mind--the kind with cookies. If you're not eating Thin Mints right now like I am, stop crying and replace your existing No Soliciting sign with this one.

There are versions with holes to hang with a standard suction cup and hook. There are also versions with no holes in case you have something else in mind.

You can easily resize this to any size you want. Simply unlock the keep aspect ratio and scale X and Y dimensions only, but leave the Z axis (height) alone. Currently, it's 180mm, which fits my print bed nicely.

How to Print:

  1. Use the Cura Change Filament plugin.

  2. Set first layer and layer height to 0.2mm.

  3. Set the change filament heights to:

    • 1.2mm
    • 1.6mm
  4. Use the colors:
    • Green
    • White
    • Yellow

If you don't have yellow, skip the change at 1.6mm.

If your green filament is too dark, simply start with white, and change the filament from white to green at 0.8mm. That will give you some white behind the green to lighten it up. Alternatively, you could use black to darken it.

Monoprice Maker Select

description.text: Scissor design spinner

This is a model of the composite knot 31#_3_1, or the composition of two overhand or trefoil knots. Since the trefoil knot comes in left and right-handed versions, there are two versions of this composite knot: the square knot 3_1 # 3_1_m, where a left-handed and right-handed trefoil are spliced together, and the granny knot 3_1 # 3_1 where two trefoils of the same handedness are spliced together. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. remixed_from.title: Left handed duplicator 6 blower cooling duct

title: Left handed duplicator 6 blower cooling duct with probe mount

description.text:
Added 1bigpig's 12mm probe mount. It's offset 5mm more to the right, so make sure you are using the following lines in the firmware config instead of the ones provided:
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 40 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -16 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

I also improved printability. The nozzles are now connected to the main part from the first layer on so they don't come off during printing anymore. I also cut off 0.2mm from the bottom of the part to increase the surface area of the circular part. Lastly I added a helper disc, that you can simply cut off, which will prevent the circular part from lifting off during the first few layers.

You need supports for the probe mount. I also added manual supports in my Slicer close to where the fan mounts inside of the circular part where the roof is horizontal. Make sure you don't add too much or it will be a pain to remove.

Notes:

Don't use PLA or PETG - it will sag if you print things at more than 200C (even with the silicone boot)

title: Tronxy P802M Z-Axis End Stop Mount

description.text:
After changing out the horrible original X-Carriage ends that came with my printer I used the parts from this Thing to replace them: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1103976

As this has no provision to mount the actuator for the Z-axis end stops I came up with this Thing.

The mount that goes on the motor and holds the microswitch came from another Thing found here but I cannot find the original Thing. If it's your's please let me know so I can credit you correctly.

Printing and assembly is simple. Print the arm and mount flat. print the spacers standing on end. Place the 17.5MM spacer and arm on the bottom two holes of the motor mount. Place the 2.5MM spacers between the switch and mount as shown in the pic.

You may need to add a pair of nuts to the height adjustment screw. It has worked it's way loose in the time since I first built this.

If I have time I may redesign the arm to capture a nut.

title: Up Mini Heat Plug
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To minimise warping, the print bed should be kept enclosed and warm.
The Up Mini has a large hole at the top where heat can escape.
This mod is to fill the gap, while maintaing the functionality of the top lid.

Remove the two bolts at the rear of the top lid.
Do not remove the lid, it needs to be in place when fitting the plug.
Bolt the plug in place using the existing holes.The original bolts are too short and need to be replaced with longer ones - I used 8mm.

comments.text:
Very unlikely if the chamber is only passively heated by the heat bed.
My mod just maintains the heat without losing it through the top of the machine.
comments.author: Woodlake

comments.text: Too much heat inside the chamber could cause the filament to grind out and not feed correctly. This is a common problem with the Up Mini 1 and 2. More heat is not always the answer, just advising caution.
comments.author: MichaelPetitclerc

comments.text:
Yes, the UPmini has a problem with too much heat.
In my experience that is not filament grinding, but the extruder motor which looses torque when too hot = loosing steps, and thus not feeding the filament constantly anymore. This is a design issue, as the extruder motor is partialy used as a heatsink for the hotend (very bad design in my eyes).
I sticked a 30x30mm heatsink with heat conductive adhesive foil to the front of the extruder motor and added a 30x30mm cooling fan on top, which can be easily plugged in one of the free ports on the PCB (just measure which pins will give you 12VDC).

title: CD Case Poster Wall
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Create a custom poster of any size you like (depending on the resolution of the source image) using the back halves of CD cases. The cases simply push onto the 3D printed "donuts" attaching to the centre clip used to hold the CD in place.

Work out how large you want your "poster" to be.
For the poster in the images, I went with 7 rows of 11 CD's which gives approximately the same aspect ratio as a 16x9 monitor. That way, I could use HD desktop wallpapers images (of course, your own photos/images could also look amazing - and unique!).
I used 3mm MDF board as a base, that way I could apply the "donuts" to the board, rather than directly to the wall, then screw fixed the board to the wall.
I painted the MDF the same colour as the wall. The donuts were attached with strong double sided tape. I found the best method was to fit the donuts to the case (with double sided tape attached) and then place them in their correct location with the board flat on the floor.
I arranged them in rows with an approximate 3mm gap all the way around them - enough space to get your fingers in to grasp the individual cases for fitting/removal.
Use a spacer to keep the distance consistant.

Photoshop was used to crop the chosen image into CD sized "chunks" (remember to allow for the gaps between the CD cases!!)
I then had them printed at a local photo place as standard 5 x 7 photos.
This gives enough room to add the image and a reference number so that you know where they go, and which way is up (they can look pretty abstract printed as lots of small squares!) - see the 3rd image for an example.
Once I had all the photos printed, I went through and copied the reference number onto the back in pencil (that way it wouldn't be lost when I cut the image out).
I used rows A to G (top to bottom) and 1 to 11 (left to right), being careful to make sure the orientation was also correct.
Cut each image out and place them into the corresponding CD case.
Continue until the whole image is complete.
It cost me 35c per photo, so this particular poster was ~$27 in printing costs.

The only tip I would offer is to not place it directly opposite a large window or light source as the CD cases are very reflective, and can make it hard to view...

I'd love to see some photos if anyone decides to give it a try.

description.text:
I wanted to create a wall mount for my various spools of filament. I've seen various bracket-and-stick approaches, but they always have the disadvantage of needing to remove the whole spool set just to get the one (inevitably) in the middle.

To solve this I created a print bracket which allows standard 20cm reels to be 'stacked' on a wall using a bracket at each end of the spool. The brackets have two slots, allowing additional brackets to be placed at appropriate intervals allowing many spools to be supported. The distance between the brackets is determined by the width of the spool you want to mount.

The disadvantage over the bracket-and-stick approach is that many different widths of spools are difficult to support since the brackets are fixed to the wall at specific separations. For me, I use only a couple of specific filament suppliers, so all my spools are the same width. Your milage may vary.

author: ustkl

description.text: This is a model of the composite knot 41#_4_1, which consists of two figure-8 knots spliced together. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this composite knot tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

remixed_from.title: Knurled Tri-Spinner EDC Fidget Widget / Triple Bearing Spinner

title: Knurled Tri-Spinner EDC Fidget Widget / Triple Bearing Spinner (Customizable)

description.text:
Same as the original, only customization is enabled (including the number of bearings).

Don't go below 3 bearings or above 6, it will look strange and it won't be useful. At least with the default size settings it will.

Main reason not to go above 6 bearings: The script times out (It won't if you open it in OpenSCAD though).

Also note that it might not be entirely symetrical at all number of bearings. So your results might vary.
I'll try to tweak it to be more stable later, if I find the time. I'm just a little worried that it might cause script timeouts, rendering it useless in the Customizer app here on Thingiverse...

I tweaked the script so the inner ring is only knurled if the number of bearings is below 7, since more than 6 outer bearings makes the inner knurling invisible anyway, so it seems like a waste of script-time to calculate it.

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=834725

Using the following options:

Rotation = 50
twist = -3
Loop_x_position = 16
Loop_y_position = 0
spacing = [10,15,11.5,9.3,8.5,8.4,8.7,15,15]
Font_name = Chewy
Text = Melissa
height = [5,6,4,5,4,3,5,4,6]
center = 60
Loop_font = Chewy
Loop_character = o

Haven't changed anything, original had only one black and assumed the user would flip the file to get the other side. Some people don't have the ability to for whatever reason. Just thought I'd make it easier and have them both together.

I did print them at 1.05 because it was a tad snug and kept pushing my screen protector off.
If you rotate and print it on its side where there's no opening, you don't need supports. Takes about 3 hrs and 40min compared to 2hrs, but I like how smooth it came out.

Will post photos this evening.

SeeMeCNC

Rostock MAX v2

No

Yes

Minimum 20%, suggested 35%

Find your blocks are sliding around too much?

Tip: Pick up rubber cement and go over the bottom of the blocks and let to dry, that way it won't move around on slippery desks. Or get sticky gel buttons from the hardware store and stick them on the corners.

Still loving my SP2 after all these years. <3

description.text: This is a model of the prime knot 5_2, which is a twist knot. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime knot, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/5_2. For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this prime knot tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

title: Anet A8 Jan 2017 model Prusa X carriage remix (4xLM8UU or 4xDrylin RJ4JP-01-08))

description.text:
Edit 14/04/2017 - Added a 46mm version

Edit 08/04/2017 - Deleted the old files and re-uploaded new files which no longer have the graphic glitch which showed one of the M4 screw holes covered over. Also remixed the gap between the rod centres to 45.5mm and 45.75mm which were requested. Also uploaded a .step file of the original so others can edit themselves. The original has 45mm between rod centres.

Edit 17/03/2017 - I added a .step file which I converted from the original .stl file so it's not perfect but it is now easier for others to remix for their machines.

Edit 14/03/2017 - I added another version of the X carriage with an extra 0.25mm separation between the bearings which should allow for smother movement using Igus Drylin RJ4JP-01-08.

I (along with others) found that the newer Anet A8 from late 2016 to Jan 2017 on wards had slightly different dimensions between the 2 x axis guide rods. The original prusa rework x carriage was very tight fitting especially towards the ends of the x axis travel range.

I have expanded this x carriage by 0.5mm between the top and bottom bearing housings to allow for this. I have found that with LM8UU bearings the fit is perfect and there is no slop at all and no binding.

To remix this for Igus bearings which have much tighter tolerance's then LM8UU bearings it might have to be expanded by another 0.5mm as I found that my printed PLA Igus replica bearings were still a bit tight on the ends of the travel. I will experiment when my Igus bearings turn up.

NOTE: Yes I am aware that one of the M4 screw holes has one end covered. This was a bug that I can't yet rectify in Fusion 360 after I split the body in two. When you load the .stl into your slicer it should go away and leave the hole open.

Printer:

Anet A8 modified

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Best printed slower for more accuracy. I printed mine at 30mm/s with 20mm/s outer wall.

comments.text: Are you measuring the gap of the rods in the middle of the X axis. This will lead to incorrect dimensions. title: Mini 0805/0803/0801 Dash Cam to Selens 36mm CPL Adapter ring

description.text:
This is an adapter ring to allow you to mount a Selens 36mm CPL to a Ambarella Mini 0805/0803/0801 dash camera.

What you will need:
a printed adapter plate (for me printed at 98% size on .stl file above gave best fit) (print in ABS!!!!)
an ambarella mini 0805/3/1 dash camera
magnetic tape or double sided tape (i used 3M double sided foam tape i had lying around which worked remarkably well - i bought some adhesive backed magnetic tape but didn't like its magnetic strength in my case)

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm z axis

Infill:

30% But could be lower

Notes:

Printed at 98% size for perfect fit for me using Simplify3D

Raft is needed as ABS warps when removing from the hotplate. (wouldn't be an issue if using tape or some other contact medium and let it cool)

Installation

Installation:
The diameter of the threading compared to that on the lens is slightly mismatched and easily jumps through the thread, however when secured as far in as possible and rotated slightly the thread engages and gives a firm hold, one i could not remove without rotating.

I did consider changing the shape and using a plug to secure it onto the camera held on by the audio jack on top. but wanted something sturdier. - food for thought for others.

As an afterthought once it was secured i decided to take a Sharpie and colour in the adapter plate black, This was just because white stood out against the black camera and lens as i printed in white ABS. from outside my car i cant tell the difference but for full stealth print in black if you can.

The lens can be removed for night driving by rotating against the adapter ring. this pops the lens out leaving the adapter plate attached but not obstructing.
The adapter plate in my case was permanently attached to the camera however i could easily isoproply alcohol the double sided tape and have it come off too for reinstallation.

After fitting the CPL i removed it and the mount stayed firmly attached, i then colored the mount blaaaaack!!

Design Program and My Story

I used solidworks to design this part, for any who have solidworks 2016-2017 feel free to download and modify, the solidworks file is attached.

My Story:
I bought an Ambarella Mini 0805 Dash Camera for my car to install myself but soon realized that the glare you get from the windshield and dash made it difficult to see number plates on the footage unless i was in shade or facing away from the sun. i discovered i needed a polarizing filter or CPL.

I went onto ebay and found the Selens 36mm CPL lens designed for the Inspire X3 or Osmo X3 drones. This was the cheapest CPL i could find at around $8 AUD / $6 US shipped from china to australia for free.

The Filter has a threaded rear component that allows it to be attached whilst a slip joint for polarization adjustments independent of the threaded section. But i had nothing and no way to mount it to on the camera so i decided to print an adapter plate. This gave the lens some surface area to then attach to the camera.

The Mount was designed with a thread incorporated into it as well as a flat back plate to stick it to the camera. The ridges on the edge of the model are for grip to allow for install or removal of the plate once fitted.

This is a model of the prime link 6_2_3. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime link, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/L6a1 For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this prime link tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

remixed_from.title: 3Dator Y-piece for dual extrusion with one nozzle

remixed_from.author: gimle
remixed_from.title: Mini dual Y adapter for E3D V6 style hotend with bowden extruders

description.text:
This is a simple Y extruder, building on the excellent work from others.
I liked the PTFE sleeved design of the flux capacitor, but found it very difficult to make the 8mm PTFE parts with accurately drilled 2mm holes. The un-sleeved designs, I thought, might suffer from wear.
So this design relies only on easily available 4mm diameter by 2mm id Teflon tube, as used in most bowden systems.
The Y part uses a split part of tube to gently feed the filament into the combined hole.
The Cut-away photo shows how it works.

After I saw Gimle's nice version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2326087 I have been re-designing this and have added a Printable M10 bowden connector.
This fits the M10 version of my Y, and also the inlet of the E3D extruder (at least those with M10 threads!).
The big advantage of this is that the 4mm PTFE tubing goes right through the connector and you can use a single piece right from the Y coupling down into the Extruder. This means that there are less places for the filament to be trapped or stick. I have sketched a section of an extruder with the Y to illustrate this.

I have included a tool to hold a common knife blade to make the special split, although I recommend actually having the blade in a knife holder rather than having the blade alone as in the photo!.

I am working on files to make this work with Cura 2.4 (on) for Delta printers and these are available at:
https://github.com/dagnall53/JSONS-for-Cura2_3
These files look after changing the filaments.

The penultimate photo shows a transparent /black print halfway through. There is lots of stringing going to the ooze tower. However, when finished, the transparency of the "transparent" PLA was significantly less than when it is printed by itself. Obviously this is a very severe test of the two filament - one nozzle concept. The final photo shows the finished indicator compared to a version made of transparent PLA and then painted black. Both have the same bulbs, but you can see the two colour print one (the lower example in the photo) has significantly dimmer illumination, due to the transparent filament printing slightly grey despite a large (~20mm square) ooze and changeover tower.

To give confidence that the tubing is being held securely, I recommend making a small mark on the tubing as it enters the bowden coupling, so you can see if it moves during printing.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm height 0.4mm nozzle

Notes:

The holes in the fittings are designed as hexagons, and aligned so that they should print without support. But the threaded holes work best if printed so they are "flat" on the bed.
I printed mine horizontally, as per the STL, and then cut / cleaned the threaded parts after printing with a 10mm*1 cutter.
The bowden coupler is "upside down" in the STL, and should be inverted before printing.

Finishing the parts and assembly.

When printed, you need to sort out the threaded parts. I have used a 10mm*1 thread cutter to clear the threads in the combiner if it is printed horizontally, as the threads tend to sag and need cutting out before the bowden coupler will fit.
If printed vertically, the threads have worked better, but I would still recommend cleaning and clearing them before attaching the bowden coupler.
If using metal couplers, these should self cut into the threads.

The 10mm bowden parts are best printed so the holes are vertical when printing, and then finished by drilling the main hole with a 4.2mm drill. I have tried using a 4mm drill, but it results in a very tight tube, and the 4.2mm drill is quite inexpensive.

The splitter tool should not need much post printing work, but running a 4.mm (or 4.2mm!) drill down each tube can make it easier to use. If it is still tight on the tubing, a 4.5mm drill works, but then the tubing may not get evenly split.

Once the splitting tool holes are clean, fit a knife blade in the splitter tool and press in a piece of PTFE tubing for about 50mm , and pull it out. You should find the end neatly split. Cut each end about 15mm from the split, at an angle to ease filament entry.

BEFORE putting the split tubing into the coupler, run a 2mm drill down the "input" shafts. It does not matter if it slightly cuts into the "opposite" shaft as this will be later covered by the split PTFE tubing.

NOW, push the split tube into the Y fitting so that the split end is about 35mm deep into the fitting.

Fitting technique #1 (for 6mm bowden connectors) Cut off the end of the PTFE tubing, and then, using a 4.5mm drill, carefully drill away the tubing down into the hole where the pneumatic fitting will go. You should end up with a neat and slightly bevelled concentric hole for the fitting, with the PTFE right in the centre.

Fitting Technique #2. (6mm coupings) I found that part of the stiffness in the fliament movement can come from the PTFE being compressed by the bottom pneumatic fitting. As an alternative, try cutting the PTFE insert (uncut part) so that it is about 1mm below the Pneumatic fitting when it is in place. Then make sure that you have nice bevelled ends to both the PTFE and Pneumatic fitting bores holes. This seems to make for a smoother filament movement.

Fitting Technique #3 (for 10mm bowden connectors). Cut the bowden tube using the splitter and fit it in the coupling, then simply screw the bowden coupler in place and tighten the coupling. Cut the tubing to a suitable length so that it fits right down into the extruder, as per the section drawing.

With the PTFE in place, test with a spare piece of filament and check all is running smoothly.

I have found that there are (at least) two types of 6mm pneumatic fittings. One has a hexagonal central hole, which I think can snag filament. The other has a circular central hole, and when this is bevelled, makes a much smoother transition for the filament. I have not found an easy way to tell these apart on Ebay!. Using my 10mm bowden couplings works very well, and means fewer tubing transitions.

I am working on making a set of .Json files for Cura 2.4(+) to make printing with this work. So far I have the setup accepting that I have dual extruders, and retracting etc as the extruders are switched. I do have some trouble with filament stringing (I am testing with ABS) , I have a push pull motion to try to avoid this programmed in the JSON's. Cura 2.4 had maths issues with centre-zero Delta printers, I am hoping 2.5 will have cured this.

Cheers!

Originally designed using 123D, I have moved to Fusion 360 and been very impressed with its capabilities. The bowden coupler, which has both straight and tapered threads, was very simple to design, and works well if your printer is reasonably well calibrated.

comments.text:
The issue for me has been trying to get nice clean retracts. By hand, I seem to get very nice clean ends with no string by withdrawing about 10mm, waiting about 1 second, then pushing back until I feel resistance and then immediately withdraw at about 50 to 100 mm/second.
But I cannot reproduce this with the drives.. I get stringing of up to 200mm of very thin filament. Plus one extruder works fine at 10000 mm/min, the other cannot manage 3000.. I plan to look at the drive electronics settings tomorrow. Presumably one driver is set at a lower current...
comments.author: 3Dator

comments.text: What i've seen other splitters do is quickly extrude 1mm or so of plastic then immediately retract, its supposed to leave a nice clean filament to pass through easily
comments.author: dagnall53

comments.text:
@Sterminare Thanks for the suggestion, I will try that.
I also updated the previous post to show my start and end codes for the extruder.
This was essentially a copy of 3dator's code. The intent was to extract , pause for the slug to cool, then push back to form the tip with a very short pause again to resist filament grind (see below) before retracting, first slowly, then faster.

author: Muthinor

title: Replicator 1/CTC/Flash Forge - Mightyboard to RAMPs 1.4 Conversion (Comprehensive Conversion!)

description.text:
UPDATE (11/17/2017): Well, it's been a while since I updated thanks to life in general. I've switched to a Duet controller after my 1st and 2nd RAMPs boards died since I had one of those laying around (from ANOTHER project I never got started on), and I needed a printer ASAP for a work project. I'm WAY happier with that than I ever was with a Mightboard or RAMPs, and between hooking it up and printing out a test print I spent MAYBE an hour or so (that included firmware configuration). I'll be writing up that conversion in the future, but if this project is any indication it may be a while. :-)

Sorry if I let anybody down. I'm still happy to answer any questions I can for anyone who is going to try and convert to RAMPs. My setup was working just fine for a while, so I'm going to add what I can to this project from my notes and my horrible memory.

Thanks for the support, all.

THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS, AND I AM NO EXPERT. Sometimes I get lucky and/or break stuff in useful/educational ways. May as well benefit the community. But, if you destroy your own printer or set your house on fire or something by following my instructions, I am not responsible for it. The liability is on you. I am trying to put forth the best, clearest tutorial possible, but I am still just some guy on the internet. :-)

The Mightyboard in my Monoprice Replicator 1 clone died, and instead of dropping the $$$ for a replacement I decided to convert it to run on RAMPS 1.4 instead.

After a lot of Googling, it seems that there wasn't a complete walk-through or tutorial to accomplish this conversion anywhere. I found a lot of bits and pieces scattered across the internet, including quite a bit of conflicting information, so I wanted to put together a comprehensive conversion guide so that you can avoid the litany of headaches I encountered. That includes wiring, firmware installation and configuration, slicer settings, etc. The end goal is simple: Convert a Replicator 1 or similar clone to RAMPS while still performing to the same level of precision or better as the original configuration.

This is an ongoing project on my end, and I'll update this as I progress. I've got my personal printer tuned it, except for a few bugs that I'm trying to sort out now.

I can't guarantee you that I will be able to help answer all your questions real-time, but I'll try to help where I can. I've got 4 kids, a full time job, and I'm carrying a full credit load at Arizona State, so this is a project that may need to get put on the back burner from time to time. If I don't respond to a question in a reasonable amount of time, please don't take it personally.

Current Printer Configuration:

My printer is not 100% stock; I've upgraded/modified a couple of parts over the past 2 years or so. Most of the changes I've already made will not alter the process of converting your printer over to run RAMPS, but when we get to the calibration and tuning part it may be slightly different. Here's the modifications I've made to my printer:

  • E3D-v6 Hotend with Volcano upgrade
  • Bowden extruder
  • Heated build plate (mine did not originally come equipped with one).

Steps (ideally):

1.) Wiring/RAMPS installation

  • Power supply changes
  • Thermocouple/thermistor changes.
  • Stepper/limit switch wiring

2.) Firmware Installation

3.) Firmware Configuration (Marlin)

4.) Slicer Configuration

  • Simplify 3D
  • Cura

5.) Maybe - Upgrades (very much a maybe)

  • Multi-extruder or dual-headed extruder (Cyclops/Chimera)
  • Auto leveling
  • Servo vs. Stepper upgrade
  • Marlin-Controlled Case Fan.

Files Attached

1.) Firmware: Marlin-1.8.1.zip

  • This is the current build and configuration I'm using.
  • The z-axis homing issue has been resolved.
  • Runaway temp settings had to be opened up to prevent false positives. It's still enabled (safety first :-).

2.) Smart LCD Display Housing

  • File: LCD_Display_Mount.stl
  • This LCD display holder was exactly what I was looking to build, but someone beat me to it.
  • Take a look at the original thing and send a "like" to the creator (xxricsxx) here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1645651

3.) E3D-V6 Dual Hotend Mount

  • File 1: Hotend_Mount-V006_Dual_Extruder_Bridge_Adjustable.STL
  • File 2: Hotend_Mount-V006_Dual_Extruder_Cooler_Adjustable.STL
  • I'm currently using this mount with a single hotend on the right side (minimized the amount of configuration changes when I swapped out the original extruder).
  • It's a derivative of a mount created by MacNite,. I modified it so that I could run fans that were 40x40x20mm instead of 40x40x10mm since there's a much better selection of thicker fans.
  • You can view the original and send a like to the original creator here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1446512

4.) Bowden Extruder with Mount

  • File 1: Bowden - Monoprice_-_Dual_Extruder_Mount.STL
  • File 2: Bowden - Monoprice_-_Dual_ExtruderMount-_Retainer.STL
  • File 3: Bowden - hook.stl
  • File 4: Bowden - level.stl
  • File 5: Bowden - tightener.stl
  • File 6: Bowden - axle.stl
  • File 7: Bowden - extruder_base_v3.stl
  • File 8: Bowden - adapter_v2.stl
  • Designed to fit the Replicator 1 design without drilling additional holes.
  • Fits 2 steppers for dual extruders.
  • Derivative of the 3Dator Bowden Extruder created by 3Dator (which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1318849)

Known Issues - Firmware

Open

  • Printer is not waiting for the extruder and bed to preheat prior to starting the print. Currently preheating the printer manually before starting the print job. That should be an easy fix, but it's fighting me for some reason...
  • After homing prior to printing, the z-axis is lowing ~18mm below where it should and it is trying to print in mid-air. I'm currently getting around this by setting my z-axis offset to -18mm in my slicer, but this is a pretty lazy fix and I'm trying to sort out what in the firmware is causing the problem.

Closed

  • Let's not get too excited. I just started updating this...

Tutorials

1.) Wiring/RAMPS Installation

Protip: When removing the harnesses from the printer for this step, label which one came from what axis or extruder.

Since my Mightyboard was dead and I never planned on replacing it with another Mightyboard, I didn't really care to preserve any of the factory connectors on any of the harnesses. My printer came with the Mightyboard Rev. D which mostly used the Molex KK-style connectors while the RAMPS shield uses Dupont-Style connectors. So, I cut off the connector on the board-side of the harness.

You can purchase kits and crimpers for the Dupont connectors on Amazon or Ebay, but I've had issues with these in the past (probably operator error) so I just purchased jumpers with the connectors I needed on them from Ebay and used them as pigtails.

We need to re-terminate the following harnesses on the board side:

  1. X/Y/Z-axis steppers
  2. Extruder(s)
  3. Endstops
  4. Heated build plate
  5. Extruder & mainboard fan

You can remove the following components. We won't be using them any more.

  1. Original LCD
  2. Keypad/SD card slot
  3. Mightyboard
  4. Ribbon cables between LCD/Keypad/Mightyboard
  5. 24VDC power supply

1. X/Y/Z-axis steppers
Both the Mightboard and RAMPS use 4 pin connectors for the steppers. It is important that you realize that the pinout on the RAMPS board is different than the Mightboard, so if you connected the steps to RAMPS and leave the connections the same pin-to-pin (e.g stepper pin 1 to RAMPS pin 1, stepper pin 2 to RAMPS pin 2, etc) you may burn up a stepper or possibly just make an annoying noise. Either way, not good.

The image below shows the stepper connections on both the Mightyboard and the RAMPS board. You can see that they are different.

If you are looking at the Mightyboard such that the ribbon cable connector is on the right side, then the pinout for the stepper motors will be (from left to right):
Pin 1 = 1A (yellow)
Pin 2 = 1B (red)
Pin 3 = 2A (black)
Pin 4 = 2B (orange)

However, if you look at the RAMPS shield such that the power connectors are on the left (the ones with the screw terminals), the pinout for the steppers is as follows:
Pin 1 = 2B
Pin 2 = 2A
Pin 3 = 1A
Pin 4 = 1B

To maintain the same ordering, connect the new connector so that the following pins connect:
MB - to - RAMPS
Pin 1 - to - Pin 3
Pin 2 - to - Pin 4
Pin 3 - to - Pin 2
Pin 4 - to - Pin 1

It should look like this when you're done wiring. You need to do this for all stepper motor harnesses and extruder harnesses.

Endstop, heater, and thermistor wiring will be added soon!

3/10/17 - Change log added; Baseline printer configuration added; Uploaded and renamed stl files for LCD housing, bowden extruders, and E3D-v6 hotend.
3/11/17 - Added stepper wiring diagram.
6/10/17 - Current firmware added (Marlin 1.8.1).

In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime link, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/L6a4 For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this prime link tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

description.text:
inspired by various laptop stands out here.

you already printed this stand, but your new laptop/tablet doen't fit any longer?
no problem! just print some additional parts, change the width and you are good to go!

bored of the single colour?
no problem! print the same parts in different colours and exchange them.

you want to cook a great meal, but have no room for the recipe book in the kitchen?
no problem! books also fit in this stand :-)

this bundle includes:

  • testing piece <== PRINT THIS FIST!!! so you can do some fine tuning, if necessary
  • L-Part (~15cm long to fit on smaller printers)
  • rods (male-male) with different length (5,10,15,20cm)
  • rod adapter (female-female) to add two rots together
  • rod additions (male-female) to expand even further (5,10,15,20cm)
  • [not finished jet] keyboard holder - will snap on the front side of the L-Part

NOTE: the male-connectors already have supports, similar to simplify3D - and they work GREAT!

thanks to Bushmills for his "simple pin and block snap connector". i benefit from it a lot.

[update 12.03.2017]
i finished the keyboard holder (06_keyboard_holder.stl). it is a small part which has to be connected to the front of the big L-part. you can put your keyboard on it and have enough room for post-processing your printed parts, while watching youtube in front of your laptop

[update 11.03.2017]
IT WORKS! (i never really had a doubt, but it's good to know for sure...)
printed in PLA. i don't have lots of experience with ABS, but warping could become a problem... try printing a long rod before starting the whole project and maybe fail.

In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime knot, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/7_1. For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. I was inspired by the Folding wallet cassette (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:123670) which worked quite nicely for me, although it left some things to be desired:
-Not enough space for cards (in those days where everybody wants to put plastic in your wallet, you can't have enough)
-Not enough room for folded paper (Bank notes, german drivers licence) especially if there are some coins in the box as well.
For that I decided to remix this source instead of the original, since I liked the ID being visible.
I raised the whole height about a mm which gives room for one to two more cards and raised the thickness of the bottom in order to withstand the strain caused by the clamp I was going to mount.
The clamp is a separate part to be screwed on to the walled by means of 3 2.2mm screws. There are two versions of the clamp:
v1 - plain vanilla clamp
v2 - added holder for a SanDisk Ultra mini USB memory stick

For the test I used black PETG from PETG tech which gives it a nice carbon fiber finish. The effect is even better when printed on glass.

description.text: This is a model of the prime link 7_2_1. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime link, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/L7a6 For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this prime link tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

title: Better Y carriage belt holder block for Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B Aluminium

description.text:
The Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro B has some good features but the Y carriage belt holder is not one. I was amused when told to "make a hole in the belt and then put a screw through it". Clearly not a design to last and sure enough, it broke after a couple of weeks.

I found the the replacement belt was thicker than the original. This has been designed in OpenScad with parameters so it could be easily adapted for other similar carriages. To fit it you will need 2 x M3 screws approx 18mm and 2 x M3 nuts (my kits had some left over).

It also has the profiles for other belts as taken from the things below.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627 by Droftarts
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19758 by doommeister

comments.text: Made one but found the slot for the belt a bit on the tight side. Tried sandpaper & a thin steel rule to open the groove, just taking too long. May be easier to have a slightly wider slot & then lock the belt in with a thin strip of shim stock (bake bean can!).
comments.author: Hensberg

title: iWatch charger old Macintosh with Keyboard & Mouse

description.text:
This is Remix of the cool - iWatch charger like an old Apple Macintosh - by guytc
To make it complete, I just added a tiny keyboard and mouse.

Because its so tiny and might get lost real quick, I drilled some tiny holes in the keyboard and Macintosh and put the curly cable through and glued it together. I would recommend to do the same for the mouse.
I also adjusted some measurements, to prevent the display getting any scratches and to fit the charger a little bit better.

title: Mecanum Wheels (2 Inch)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was a project that I have been working on for a few months on an off. The wheels are a little larger than 2 inches ind diameter. The are designed to be used on the Tamiya 3mm shaft gearboxes. These where the ones that where featured on the Make: website.
http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2010/04/3d-printable_mecanum_wheel.html There are two versions of the .STL The one that ended in inches is the one I used for the 3d-print. The other one should be in millimeters. For some reason the file size is different. The .STl files are large. Download the zip file not the .STL
Print using a commercial Printer such as a Dimension SST. Assemble using a 3/32 brass rod or tube.

description.text:
This is a bottle cap with threads and a center hole for projects.

It's 30mm in diameter and 14mm high and intended to be merged with other projects in the slicer.
That makes designing things that use a Pet-bottle as container easier, since there only needs to be a 30mm hole that's 14mm deep in the position where the bottle shall be.

I've been using it for a cat-feeder that will be uploaded as soon as it's ready.

This fit Coca-Cola, Fanta and more bottles.

I've also included the Solidworks partfile if someone has more use with that.

Printer:

AnetA8

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,1

Infill:

10%+

Notes:

Recommended to use a low resolution to make the threads better.

comments.text: Very nice.  Thanks for including the sldprt file.  I printed the cap as a test and it fits great.  I am using it to make a sharps container for my insulin needles.  Printing my first attempt at it now.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

Both designs works great in ABS, T-glass or TPU A100+

description.text:
Description

Very rough model of Raspberry PI 3. Useful as subtraction for creating cases for the PI.

Usage (in OpenSCAD)

  1. Create a box which represents your case
  2. Substract the PI
  3. Print the case
  4. Your real PI will fit into the printed case

Example

use <RaspberryPi.scad>;

difference() {
    cube([89,60,4]);
    translate([2,2,3])RaspberryPi3();
}

This is a model of the prime knot 7_2. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime knot, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/7_2. For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this prime knot tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

Description

Very rough model of the stepper motor 28BYJ (http://www.instructables.com/id/BYJ48-Stepper-Motor/). Useful as subtraction for creating holder plates for the motor.

Usage (in OpenSCAD)

  1. Create a box which represents your holder plate
  2. Substract the motor
  3. Print the plate
  4. Your real motor will fit into the printed plate

Example (see TestBox.scad)

use <Stepper.scad>;

difference() {
    cube([40,50,4],center=true);
    translate([0,0,2.5])28BYJ();
}

title: Happy New Year-Magic key to the 4th dimension … universal mobile solar clock

description.text:
Trying to imagine what to make in 2014 … I thought … maybe the man stood up to look at the horizon beyon blades of grass … maybe indicating stars form the top of a mountain he discovered hands … maybe they built machines to fly and from stars to look at the night becoming a little shadow while the time becoming movement … maybe we explored the third dimension to reach the forth … Happy New Year to all those clambing mountains with hands at night … if I succeed in 2014 I will try to share something about time
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ty5krc4oiz0

I thought and made at night … after drinking a little and having little time and pla to make tests … “one shot one kill” … then I realized 3 pieces of 10 cm (bonded by heating) but surely it can be worth to make them bigger and maybe with some effort it can be made in a single block … pictures show the logic of his functioning, triangle (triangle file) has to be modified following latitude … for example, I am in Italy and then I put an angle of 45 degrees … to have the exact time then there are more lengthy calculations which correct the "errors" for each month as a function of latitude... it's interesting to study the logic because in doing it you discover how space and time are linked … “looking for when you are you find where you are” … For this reason this little clock is a key for 4th dimension … take a look at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sundial

description.text: This is a model of the prime knot 7_5. It is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. These are easier to print without as much support material. For more information about this prime knot, look at its page in the Knot Atlas http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/7_5. For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength. For ropelength data, see http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/papers/. To see a movie of this prime knot tightening, visit http://www.jasoncantarella.com/movs.

This knot shape is created by my knot tightening program RidgeRunner, which is freely available at http://www.jasoncantarella.com/wordpress/software/ridgerunner/ RidgeRunner uses a numerical algorithm to minimize the length of a knot while preserving a tube around the knot. This is only one possible position for this (topological) knot; minimizing a function other than length would give you a different shape for the model.

This is a remix of the hypercube Z Shaft Clamp v1.1

I have recreated the original in openscad and then extended it.

Having one of the bolts behind the smooth rod bugged me greatly, so this version you can use the holes left or right of the smooth rod or both. This makes adjusting the position of Z rods much easier

Secondly my smooth rod extents to the floor. The printer can't use this. So this version allows you to set the variable "lowerit" and the clamp side of the model is lowered by the specified amount.
This should give a few more mm in the Z axis without new hardware. I have uploaded a 10mm lower version, but you can set the size you want

Code is mostly parametric, but not 100%

Z_Shaft_Clamp_v1.11p added that lets you change the t-slot size

title: AsterMax Delta printer extended volume extra solid frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Order a 3D Print

Anyone interested, I sell one printer partial finished without heat bed, without firmware.
Build volume is 300mm*850mm approx
You get the printer from the pictures with UK plug wire. Power supply is 110-220v - 30A 10-14VDC. The hot end is the new Genuine e3d v6 all metal + Genuine Titan extruder with motor. All files available here for download.
In addition you get and 3 set magnets in total ( for HotEnd, laser and engraver ), however just the effector with hotend mount is finished and I will provide you with STEP file for you to design the mount for any other add-on you may need to fit.

Buy it from eBay for $780

Buy it from my website for $699

AsterMax delta 3D printer designed for simple assembly, use and maintenance in mind.

I am continuously updating the parts lists below.

The printer build uses 2020 and 2040 aluminum extrusions to keep the low cost while building a solid and simple design printer.

The current size is for a Ф300x820-850mm build volume.

Using 2020 and 2040 T-slot extrusions is a requirement, otherwise, the parts will not fit!!

A list of all the parts needed to complete the build are below and updated weekly.

Plastic parts for print:
1 x of each XYZ lower vertex (PLA)
3 x Upper vertex (PLA)
3 x top bearing guide (ABS)
3 x limit switch holder (ABS)
3 x T-slot slider (ABS)
3 x Aluminum pipe slide for multi head effector (Print the parts with low print speed ) (ABS)
1 x Effector set ( finished for just genuine e3d v 6 to fit as I want to swap hot end-laser-engraver ) (ABS)
1 x Effector set with slides for Traxxas joints if you just need it as 3D printer (ABS)

I use ABS for some of the parts as I am planing to add integrated printer enclosure with heating control for printing big parts from ABS.

BOM:
4 x Nema 17 stepper motor
3 x 16 teeth GT2 pulleys
3 x 16 teeth GT2 Idler
10 meters GT2 Belt
9 x 395mm T-Slot 2020 aluminum
3 x 1390 mm T-Slot 2040 aluminum
1 x Arduino Mega 2560
1 x Ramps 1.4
1 x LCD 2004 Display Controller
4mm Male Right Hand Thread Rod End Joint Bearing Metric Thread M4x0.7mm
OD 6mm x ID 4mm aluminum pipe
9 x V slot mini Delrin wheels
3 x mini limit switch
M3 bolts various sizes
M5 x 10mm button head bolt
M5 T-slot nuts
1 x 360W 12DCV power supply
40A DC-AC Solid State Relay Module
Male AC Power Cord Inlet Plug Socket With Rocker Switch
AC Power Wall Cord Cable Plug
Traxxas joints

All above links are affiliate and when you are clicking and buying from them you are supporting my work and this will lead to more cool designs.

author: SupplySergeant

description.text:
St. Patrick used the shamrock to explain the holy trinity with each leaf representing the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. The three leaves of a shamrock are also said to stand for faith, hope and love. A fourth leaf is where we get the luck from. The four-leafed clover, or “lucky clover”, is an uncommon variation of the three-leafed clover, and widely considered to be a symbol of good luck. Because they are a mutation, they are rare, and not found in the same abundance as the shamrock, and thus, considered lucky. The traditional Irish symbol of a shamrock does not include the fourth leaf.

These are fun, easy prints that take up just a tiny amount of filament. One of the cool features of a soft flexible like NinjaFlex (SH=85A) or Filaflex (SH = 82A) is that it sticks really well to windows and mirrors when printed at 1mm to 3mm thickness. It's important that your print surface and the windows you stick the decals on are clean ;) to insure smooth against smooth. Just wet with water and stick. I have some up in my office that have been there for almost a year. If you don't have any flexible filament you can buy some magnets at a craft store and turn these into refrigerator magnets. I started with images downloaded from pixabay.com from their public domain section and edited them for printing.

I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of several brands of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

So my wife is a volleyball coach and she is usually the first person in the gym every morning. title: H300 Mk.2 "Wasp" quadcopter frame for FPV

description.text:
Things need to be upgraded. :-) This is a remix of my original design with some improvements and new ideas.

New frame design is lighter, more rigid, more modular and provides more variability and space. Provided images show only small selection of all possible setups.

arm_M3 is for 22xx motors (M3 screws 19x16)
arm_M2 is for 18xx motors (M2 screws 16x12)

No more long screws and locknuts needed. You need 20mm aluminum spacers with 5mm hex profile and M3 thread. See https://hobbyking.com/en_us/3x20mm-alu-light-weight-round-stand-red.html

Print 4 arms and 2 frame plates (long or short, as needed). Pick 8 spacers and 16 M3x8 screws and you're done, it's all for basic frame setup.

Update 2017-04-29:

  • Reinforced frame plates (less vibrations go to FC)
  • Added frame plate for FC with standard 30x30mm mounting holes (Betaflight F3)
  • Added camera holders for Eachie 1000TVL CCD camera (0, 10, 20, 30 degrees)

Current flight configuration:

  • Printed parts: arm_M3 (4 pcs), frame_plate_long_v2_30x30_spacers, frame_plate_long_camera_cutout_v2, landing_gear_v2 (2 pcs), 1000tvl_30deg
  • Flight controller: Betaflight F3 all-in-one (FC, PDB, OSD, BEC)
  • Motors: Black Widow 2204 1900 KV with built-in ESC
  • Props: Graupner Copterprop 6x3
  • Battery: Turnigy Nanotech 3S 1500mAh
  • Camera: Eachine 1000TVL CCD
  • VTX: FT48X Raceband

Takeoff weight: 480g

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Supports needed only for arms.

When printing landing gear, disable top and bottom solid layers, you'll save some weight and get some elasticity.

title: Camera and Laser mount for Makerscanner

description.text:
This is an easy to print Logitech 9000 camera and Black Decker line laser mount for Makerscanner software.
I wanted to try 3D scanning, but didn't want to spend a whole lot of money to do it. I have a great camera, the Logitech 9000 and a cheap Black and Decker BDL220S line laser from Walmart for $20. Other methods require printing arms to connect the components together, I chose to use 3/8" wood dowel... quick and easy. The tripod mount is optional and can be printed later.

All parts were printed on a TOM with a MK6+ on a heated build platform. My settings were: Object infill% 35, Layer height(mm) .32, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 32. BOM:
Logitech 9000 camera
Black and Decker BDL220s line laser

3/8" wood dowel Print the camera and laser mounts. Cut two pieces of 3/8" dowel 165mm long. Connect the camera and laser mounts with the dowel, don't glue them, they stay together just fine. There is a magnet on the bottom of the laser, install a small #6 countersunk wood screw in the mount to keep the laser in place.There's a seem on the bottom of the laser and you made need to put a couple of layers of tape on one side to keep the laser from rocking. The camera folds up and slides into the mount without modification. The optional tripod mount uses a 1/4"x20 nut and simply slides on the dowel. As a finishing touch I added small cushions to the bottom of the mounts. There's and excellent tutorial on 3D laser scanning here: http://wiki.makerbot.com/makerscanner-software

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8XHl3bKp05C

I had always wondered how the mechanical counters worked, and it turned out to be nothing like the way I thought it would be, but something simpler and more elegant. Having discovered this I worked out this design that could be 3D printed. Research on the Internet several designs that kept all the gearing internal to the number reels, but the one that is more appropriate to help with the understanding of the workings was the one shown on the left. This has 3 number reels that allow you to count to 999 and uses a lost motion gear pair in between each reel, that transfers the motion to the next reel after 1 complete revolution of the lower digit reel.

This design is based on the model developed by Matthias Wandel, you can see it here http://woodgears.ca/counter/index.html
I have changed some of the features to make it suitable for 3D printing, and simplified the Actuator and made it a simple push operation.

For complete instructions got to http://www.3dprinterclocks.com/page23.html

Printer Brand:

Zortrax

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.19 mm

Infill:

Medium

Notes:

I used ABS for all the parts, and you will need 1 of each STL part except for the following:-
Counter Front/Back - 2
Counter reel 2 - 2
Lost motion  - 2
Lost motion -Drive Pin - 2

You will need some extra components to complete the build:-

1 piece Ø 2 mm steel rod 80 mm long
2 piece Ø 2 mm steel rod 100 mm long
2 Springs as used in a retractable pen

You may also need a:-

Ø2 mm drill for the 3 holes in the Mainframe for securing then ends of the Ø2mm shafts.
A Ø2.1 mm drill for drilling out the bores in the parts that are a running fit on those shafts.
Acetone to solvent bond some of the parts together.

Note!
The 4 components that make up the frame are held together with Tabs and Slots, these need to be a tight fit but not that tight that you find it impossible to dismantle them again once test fitted. I would suggest therefore that you adjust the tightness with a file until the fit seems reasonable but not excessive.
